metadata.research_call: This funding organization is dedicated to catalyzing multidisciplinary scientific teams to synthesize publicly available data to address fundamental questions related to emergence phenomena in the molecular and cellular biosciences. It supports community-scale synthesis and integration of existing molecular and cellular data to: Answer novel questions Solve long-standing puzzles in the molecular and cellular sciences Develop innovative research and analytical strategies Tap diverse new talent Train the future data-savvy workforce A community-scale synthesis project has three defining characteristics. First, it uses only existing publicly available data and often integrates distinct datasets together. It does not generate any new experimental data. Second, the project is beyond the capabilities of most individual research labs and instead requires collaboration between two or more labs. Finally, such a project requires diverse scientific perspectives and expertise to come together, often resulting in novel, deeper, and broader insights. You research should focus on well-defined scientific questions or methodological developments that advance molecular and cellular sciences through synthesis research to acquire insights from a collaborative, transdisciplinary approach. This RFP invites proposals for Working Groups that will: Address Compelling Scientific Questions: Tackle novel and significant research questions in molecular and cellular biology through data synthesis. Stimulate Cross-Disciplinary Collaboration: Bring together researchers from diverse fields. Utilize Publicly Available Data: Leverage existing data sources to develop innovative research and analytical strategies. Require NCEMS Support and Resources: The proposed synthesis project must demonstrate a clear need for NCEMS support that goes beyond the capabilities of a single lab or existing collaboration. Promote Collaborative Partnerships: Assemble teams that reflect a range of scientific expertise, geographic locations, career stages, and institutional research levels. Adhere to Open Science Principles: Commit to making findings, data, and analysis workflows publicly available in accordance with community-created policies on open, team, and reproducible science. Train the Next Generation: Provide training opportunities to trainees (graduate students and postdocs) through collaborative research efforts within the working group.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Spatial Omics Data to Reveal Tissue-Specific Gene Regulation Patterns
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize spatial omics data from diverse tissues to elucidate tissue-specific gene regulation patterns. By integrating spatial transcriptomics, ATAC-seq, and histological imaging data, we aim to identify spatially resolved regulatory mechanisms that control gene expression in different cellular contexts. This initiative will involve collaboration between bioinformaticians, molecular biologists, and anatomists. NCEMS support will be essential for managing large-scale datasets and performing advanced spatial analysis. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in spatial omics data integration.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Environmental and Genomic Data to Understand Microbial Community Assembly
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize environmental and genomic data from diverse ecosystems to understand the assembly rules of microbial communities. By integrating metagenomic, metatranscriptomic, and environmental metadata, we aim to identify environmental factors that shape microbial community structures. The project will involve microbiologists, ecologists, and computational biologists to develop integrative models. NCEMS support will be crucial for handling large-scale datasets and performing advanced analyses. Results will be made openly accessible, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will learn about cutting-edge methods in microbial ecology and gain skills in data-driven discovery.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Epigenetic and Environmental Data to Investigate Epigenetic Plasticity in Plants
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize epigenetic and environmental data from plants under different growth conditions to investigate the plasticity of epigenetic marks in response to environmental stimuli. By integrating DNA methylation, histone modification, and environmental metadata, we aim to identify key environmental factors that modulate epigenetic states. The project will involve plant biologists, epigeneticists, and environmental scientists to develop integrative models. NCEMS support will be necessary for handling large-scale datasets and performing advanced analyses. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in epigenetics and environmental biology.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Single-Cell Data to Analyze Neural Stem Cell Heterogeneity in Brain Development
research_ideas.abstract: This initiative will synthesize single-cell RNA sequencing data from neural stem cells during brain development to analyze cellular heterogeneity. By integrating scRNA-seq data from multiple developmental stages and conditions, we aim to identify key subpopulations and their roles in neural development. The project will involve neuroscientists, developmental biologists, and bioinformaticians to develop innovative analytical tools. NCEMS support will be essential for managing and analyzing large-scale datasets. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in single-cell analysis.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Multi-Omic Data to Understand the Impact of Microbiome on Host Metabolism
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize multi-omic data from host-microbiome interactions to understand the impact of the microbiome on host metabolism. By integrating metagenomic, metatranscriptomic, and host transcriptomic data, we aim to identify key metabolic pathways and regulatory networks influenced by the microbiome. The project will involve microbiologists, metabolomics experts, and computational biologists to develop integrative models. NCEMS support will be necessary for handling complex multi-omic data and performing advanced analyses. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will learn about cutting-edge methods in microbiome and metabolomics and gain skills in data-driven discovery.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Structural and Functional Data to Understand Protein Dynamics in Membrane Proteins
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize structural and functional data from membrane proteins to understand their dynamic behavior. By integrating cryo-EM, X-ray crystallography, and functional assays, we aim to identify key structural features that govern protein dynamics. The project will involve structural biologists, biochemists, and computational biologists to develop integrative models. NCEMS support will be critical for handling large-scale datasets and performing advanced analyses. Results will be made openly accessible, and findings will be published in open-access databases. Trainees will learn about cutting-edge methods in structural biology and gain skills in data-driven discovery.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Single-Cell Data to Explore Immune Cell Dynamics in Autoimmune Diseases
research_ideas.abstract: This initiative will synthesize single-cell RNA sequencing data from autoimmune diseases to understand the dynamics of immune cell populations. By integrating scRNA-seq data from multiple autoimmune conditions and patient samples, we aim to identify key immune cell subsets and their roles in disease progression. The project will involve immunologists, rheumatologists, and bioinformaticians to develop innovative analytical tools. NCEMS support will be essential for managing and analyzing large-scale datasets. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in single-cell analysis.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Single-Cell Data to Analyze Cardiac Cell Heterogeneity During Development
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize single-cell RNA sequencing data from cardiac cells during development to analyze cellular heterogeneity. By integrating scRNA-seq data from multiple developmental stages and conditions, we aim to identify key subpopulations and their roles in cardiac development. The project will involve cardiologists, developmental biologists, and bioinformaticians to develop innovative analytical tools. NCEMS support will be essential for managing and analyzing large-scale datasets. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in single-cell analysis.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Spatial Omics Data to Reveal Organ-Specific Gene Regulation Patterns in Cancer
research_ideas.abstract: This project will synthesize spatial omics data from cancer tissues to elucidate organ-specific gene regulation patterns. By integrating spatial transcriptomics, ATAC-seq, and histological imaging data, we aim to identify spatially resolved regulatory mechanisms that control gene expression in different cancer types. The project will involve oncologists, bioinformaticians, and anatomists to develop integrative models. NCEMS support will be essential for managing large-scale datasets and performing advanced spatial analysis. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in spatial omics data integration.

research_ideas.title: Synthesizing Single-Cell Data to Explore Immune Cell Dynamics in Inflammation and Repair
research_ideas.abstract: This initiative will synthesize single-cell RNA sequencing data from inflammation and repair processes to understand the dynamics of immune cell populations. By integrating scRNA-seq data from various inflammation and repair conditions, we aim to identify key immune cell subsets and their roles in tissue repair. The project will involve immunologists, pathologists, and bioinformaticians to develop innovative analytical tools. NCEMS support will be essential for managing and analyzing large-scale datasets. Results will be shared openly, and findings will be published in open-access journals. Trainees will gain experience in interdisciplinary research and learn state-of-the-art methods in single-cell analysis.
